stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on the "oil Blargg" ("black boss") encounter: adds a flee/panic run behavior and damage feedback, discusses how to telegraph soap-based attacks (strike workers/janitor Koopa throwing soap), and lists remaining mechanics (moving grills, oil-floor damage, particles, teleporting). Mid-stream he identifies a looming N64 ROM-size problem driven primarily by streamed music (sound data dominating the build), forcing a strategy change for future courses.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete boss-fight design/telegraphing decisions plus a major production constraint reveal: the project is approaching the 64MB ROM cap largely due to streamed music, requiring a shift in audio/asset strategy for remaining courses.

findings.summary: The oil Blargg boss fight core loop is: Blargg repeats attacks and shoots wave hazards; periodically a soap piece drops/arrives; Mario rides the soap to ram Blargg during a distinct damage phase, repeated ~3 times to win.
Kaze adds (and likes) a panic "fleeing" run animation that speeds up and shakes more while Mario is on top (taking damage), to sell fear/pain and make the chase readable.
findings.quote: This reminds me of the Knuckles fight with King Boom Boom.

findings.summary: Remaining encounter tasks are enumerated: make Blargg disappear while fleeing and reappear elsewhere; make grills/platforms move up/down independently; add punishment if player fails to return to safe soap/platform area; add particles when soap hits; make oil floor damage Mario; tune soap to deplete faster.

Kaze is actively managing difficulty and skill-gap: he rejects ideas that would make the fight more skill-based (e.g., Blargg growing back over time) because he doesn't want a large gap between weak and strong players.
findings.quote: I don't want the gap between like a bad player and a good player to be too big.

findings.summary: Telegraphing plan for soap delivery shifts toward diegetic helpers: "strike workers" (and specifically a janitor Koopa who didn’t strike) will be visible in nearby jail cells and throw soap bars into the arena with sparkles/sound and bounce arcs so the player naturally notices without intrusive prompts.

Damage feedback will use an N64 combiner/primitive color flash on the Blargg; Kaze debates color choice and concludes blue doesn’t read well, considering orange/green instead; he also notes the flash must reset cleanly after the damage window.

A bug appears where the damage flash shows incorrect green due to what Kaze suspects is overflow; additional issues include the glow not resetting and opacity values going negative (e.g., "opacity -11"), requiring safeguards.
Kaze calls out tooling limitations: Fast64/Frost64 'switch bones' are unreliable for him, and he complains about animation property resets and GeoASM node constraints in the exporter workflow.
findings.quote: Switch bones suck in Frost64. Fuck everything up.

findings.summary: Kaze describes an optimization philosophy for N64 constraints: he avoids adding new fields to the global object struct (costing 4 bytes per object) and prefers reusing unused variables over increasing per-object memory footprint; he pushes back on dynamic-sized object data due to alignment/heap/GC overhead.
findings.quote: That would expand the object struct and we would lose four bytes for every object in the entire world.

findings.summary: A key production constraint emerges: the ROM is ~45.9MB with 11/15 courses done, and sound data alone is ~35.6MB; ~70% of the build is music, largely streamed audio that can’t be easily compressed because it must be streamed from ROM.
findings.quote: Two-thirds of the ROM is just music.

findings.summary: To stay within the 64MB ROM target, Kaze expects to reduce use of streamed songs going forward (likely starting around Course 12), selectively converting some tracks to sequenced music (worse fidelity and higher CPU cost) and possibly freeing ~1–2MB without quality loss via general cleanup.
findings.quote: We probably have to go to course 12 without a streamed song.

findings.summary: Kaze reiterates a guiding design stance: he dislikes 'chore-like' game structures (forced character swaps, key-gating, 100% completion padding) and wants to avoid frustration/interruptions like button prompts or text popups for core mechanics.
findings.quote: Video games are not supposed to be chores!

findings.summary: Chat feedback influences moment-to-moment decisions: viewers suggest stronger hit feedback (particles, crying/shaking, mouth shape), soap depletion tuning, risk/reward for returning to platform, and alternative arena theming (junkyard/warehouse/cave mix).

Badub delivered a new track for the boombox Koopas; Kaze plays/reacts to it on stream and frames it as 'really good,' implying ongoing pipeline of custom music assets that also impacts ROM size planning.

Kaze announces he and Zeina bought a house and expect to move on the 23rd; he anticipates working from a windowless 'dungeon' space, suggesting a near-term schedule disruption and a new work environment.
findings.quote: We bought a house, guys, by the way. We’re moving on 23rd likely.

biobak.summary: Asked how the game will communicate that the soap is used to attack Blargg; suggested adding particles on soap contact for clarity; provided feedback on facial expression/eyebrows and readability of damage feedback from the camera angle (often from behind).

Engaged Kaze with detailed N64 combiner math questions (multitex/prim/shade blending), leading to an on-stream explanation of smoothly interpolating between texture and primitive color for glow/damage effects.

badub.summary: Provided a new music track specifically for the boombox Koopas; Kaze highlights it during the stream as a recent addition.

Badub’s earlier suggestions are referenced indirectly regarding ROM/multi-stem strategies (e.g., repeating streamed beats with sequenced instruments), indicating composer involvement in technical audio tradeoffs.

findings.summary: Discussed Fast64 limitations/errors (GeoASM nodes/children, animation property resets), and generally served as a tooling sounding board as Kaze debugged exporter behaviors.

Suggested a mechanic where Blargg gets bigger again if the player waits too long (due to moving through oil), which Kaze rejected to avoid widening the skill gap; also gave texture/material feedback (tree stump texture/material replacement discussion).
Suggested additional boss behaviors (turning to look at Mario, panicked side-to-side head motion), and arena theme alternatives (junkyard/oil tankers/warehouse).

key_stories.title: Making the oil Blargg fight readable: fleeing behavior and damage feedback
key_stories.summary: Kaze brings in substantial off-stream progress to the oil Blargg boss and focuses on the missing readability pieces: how Blargg reacts under soap damage and how the player understands the intended tactic. He implements and tunes a panic flee animation and starts integrating a primitive-color flashing damage effect, while weighing camera angle readability and hit feedback.
key_stories.challenge: The boss needed clearer state changes (taking damage, fleeing) and more satisfying feedback; the intended soap mechanic also needed to be self-explanatory without UI prompts.
key_stories.process: He adds a flee action that chooses directions away from Mario, speeds/shakes the animation during damage, and experiments with combiner-based primitive color flashing. He discusses adding particles and changing the flash color (blue vs orange/green) and lists remaining encounter mechanics (teleporting, moving grills, oil damage, soap depletion).
key_stories.outcome: A strong baseline flee animation is in and liked; damage flash is partially working but has reset/overflow bugs and needs better color/visibility. The team converges on adding particles and faster soap depletion, with additional mechanics scheduled for later/off-stream.
key_stories.key_quote: I don't want the gap between like a bad player and a good player to be too big.

key_stories.title: Diegetic tutorial: strike workers and a janitor Koopa throw the soap
key_stories.summary: While planning how soap enters the arena, Kaze pivots toward an in-world explanation: imprisoned strike workers and a single non-striking janitor Koopa help Mario by throwing soap bars into the fight. He rejects interruptive text/button prompts and instead plans to rely on animation, sparkles, sound, and bounce arcs.
key_stories.challenge: How to communicate and deliver the soap mechanic naturally, especially if helpers are off-camera (ceiling cages) or the arena is visually busy.
key_stories.process: He brainstorms staging (side jail cells vs ceiling cages), camera constraints, and bounce trajectories that sweep across the arena. He proposes placing the janitor Koopa visibly in a side cell with a bucket so players can identify the helper over time.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete plan emerges: side cells with visible helpers, soap thrown with sparkles/sound and predictable bounces, avoiding explicit UI interruptions.

key_stories.title: ROM size crisis driven by streamed music
key_stories.summary: Kaze checks the build size and realizes the project is tracking slightly over budget relative to a 15-course plan under a 64MB cap. He identifies streamed music as the dominant cost: ~35.6MB of sound data and ~70% of total ROM size.
key_stories.challenge: Continuing to add courses and music risks exceeding 64MB, undermining the 'real N64-compatible' target and limiting content/audio ambitions.
key_stories.process: He considers options: converting selected tracks to sequenced music (quality/performance tradeoffs), possibly mono, and general cleanup to reclaim ~1–2MB. He notes streamed audio can’t be easily compressed because it must be streamed from ROM.
key_stories.outcome: Strategic shift: reduce streamed songs in remaining courses (possibly Course 12 onward) and selectively use sequenced tracks while managing CPU cost.
key_stories.key_quote: We probably have to go to course 12 without a streamed song.

key_stories.title: Why Kaze avoids adding 'just one variable'
key_stories.summary: During discussion about tracking boss hits and other state, Kaze explains that adding a new object variable globally costs 4 bytes per object across the entire world, which is expensive at N64 scale. He rejects dynamic-sized per-object data due to heap management, alignment, and performance overhead.
key_stories.challenge: Implementing new gameplay state without bloating memory/performance across all objects.
key_stories.process: He searches for unused existing fields to repurpose instead of expanding structs, and argues against per-object unique variable sets that would require more complex memory systems.
key_stories.outcome: A clear engineering constraint and guiding practice is stated for the whole project: reuse object fields; keep object sizes static; avoid runtime memory complexity.

key_stories.title: Arena theming trouble leads to a warehouse/cave pivot
key_stories.summary: Kaze becomes dissatisfied with the boss room’s look—cages look bad, lighting feels wrong, and the 'oil barrel interior' texture repetition isn’t working. He brainstorms a new theme: a gated-off oil warehouse built into a cave, with a rectangular/cuboid visual framing even if gameplay stays circular.
key_stories.challenge: The fight arena needed to feel coherent (oil/industrial/prison theme) and visually gated so players can’t see out, while still supporting platforming and camera readability.
key_stories.process: He experiments with lighting direction (fixing a normal-axis mistake), rejects certain textures, and explores junkyard/oil tanker/warehouse references before deciding on a container/metal + rock cave hybrid.
key_stories.outcome: Decision-in-progress: shift to a half-metal/half-rock "container + cave" warehouse vibe; he plans to redo water/oil visuals off-stream.
